abstract.text: A node that renders its children into a separate buffer, optionally applying an effect, before drawing the final result.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object renders its children into a buffer and optionally applies a Core Image filter to this rendered output. Because effect nodes conform to

, you can also use them to apply distortions to nodes that don’t implement the protocol, such as shape and video nodes. Use effect nodes to incorporate sophisticated special effects into a scene or to cache the contents of a static subtree for faster rendering performance.
Each time a new frame is rendered using the effect node, the effect node follows these steps:
It draws its children into a private framebuffer.
It applies a Core Image effect to the private framebuffer. This stage is optional; see the
It blends the contents of its private framebuffer into its parent’s framebuffer, using one of the standard sprite blend modes.
It discards its private framebuffer. This step is optional; see the

abstract.text: Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
A node that masks pixels drawn by its children so that only some pixels are seen.
A node that renders its children into a separate buffer, optionally applying an effect, before drawing the final result.
The values of each attribute associated with the node’s attached shader.
The blend mode used to draw the node’s contents into its parent’s framebuffer.
The Core Image filter to apply.
Sets an attribute value for an attached shader.
A custom shader that is called when the effect node is blended into the parent’s framebuffer.
A Boolean value that determines whether the effect node automatically sets the filter’s image center.
A Boolean value that determines whether the effect node applies the filter to its children as they are drawn.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the results of rendering the child nodes should be cached.
Gets the value of a shader attribute.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
A node that allows its children to rotate in 3D.

Understand how SpriteKit layers your scene’s nodes from top to bottom.
Play video in your scene by adding a video node.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
